questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of potency of anesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Potency is inversely proportional to MAC i.e. agents with high MAC will have low MAC.

N2O has the highest MAC, hence it is least potent. Methoxyflurane has the lowest MAC, hence it is the most potent.

The potency of inhalational anesthetic agents is measured inversely by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC).

  • Potencyis inversely proportional to MAC (lower MAC = higher potency).
  • Methoxyflurane has the lowest MAC among these agents, making it the most potent.
  • Nitrous Oxide (N2O) has the highest MAC, making it the least potent.

Sequence Explanation:

  1. Methoxyflurane: Most potent (lowest MAC).
  2. Halothane: Next most potent after Methoxyflurane.
  3. Isoflurane: Less potent than Halothane.
  4. N2O: Least potent (highest MAC).

Key Takeaway:

The potency of anesthetic agents follows the sequence Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > N2O, as determined by their MAC values.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetic causes hypertension
questions.solution:
All local anesthetics are vasodilators except cocaine. It has vasoconstrictor properties, so it can cause hypertension.

Cocaine inhibits the uptake of norepinephrine by premotor neurons and thus potentiates neurogenic vasoconstriction.

  • Cocaine is unique among local anesthetics as it causes vasoconstriction rather than vasodilation.
  • It inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine in sympathetic nerve endings, which leads to increased norepinephrine levels, resulting in vasoconstriction and hypertension.

Incorrect Options:

  1. Lignocaine:
    • Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a commonly used local anesthetic that causes vasodilation at the site of application.
    • It does not cause hypertension.
  2. Bupivacaine:
    • Bupivacaine is another local anesthetic with a longer duration of action.
    • While it is cardiotoxic in high doses, it causes vasodilation, not hypertension.
  3. Prilocaine:
    • Prilocaine is less cardiotoxic than bupivacaine and also causes vasodilation.
    • It is unlikely to result in hypertension.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine is the only local anesthetic that causes vasoconstriction and hypertension due to norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.
  • All other local anesthetics (e.g., Lignocaine, Bupivacaine, Prilocaine) are vasodilators and do not increase blood pressure.

questions.text:
For iv cannula in new-born, which of the following is correct?
A) 22G cannula
B) 24 G cannula
C) Adhesive patch
D) Normal saline
E) 5 ml syringe
questions.solution:
24 G canula is used in neonates.

Normal saline is used for flushing.

5 ml syringe is used for flushing normal saline.

22 G canula is not used for neonates.

choices.text: Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients
Induction and muscle relaxant given simultaneously to facilitate intubation

questions.solution:
Rapid Sequence Induction(RSI) is a specialized method of IV induction commonly used when an increased risk of gastric regurgitation and pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents exists and not for cardiac arrest patients.

High volume low pressure cuff is used.

After adequate preoxygenation and while cricoid pressure is applied, an induction dose of IV anesthetic is rapidly followed by 1-1.5mg/kg of succinylcholine(muscle relaxant) and the trachea is intubated without attempts at PPV.

  • Preoxygenation with 100% for 3 minutes is done:
    • Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for at least 3 minutes is done to maximize the oxygen reserves before intubation, ensuring better safety during the procedure.
  • High-volume low-pressure cuff used:
    • A high-volume low-pressure cuff is used on the endotracheal tube to reduce the risk of tracheal damage and prevent aspiration.
  • Induction and muscle relaxant given simultaneously to facilitate intubation:
    • Both the induction agent(such as an anesthetic) and the muscle relaxant (like succinylcholine) are administered simultaneously to facilitate rapid intubation.

Incorrect Option:

  • Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients:
    • RSI is not the method of choice for cardiac arrest patients. In cardiac arrest, the primary focus is on chest compressions and defibrillation, and intubation is done when necessary but not using RSI. Cardiac arrest patients often do not require the preoxygenation and muscle relaxants that are central to the RSI technique.

Key Takeaway:

  • RSI is a technique used primarily in cases where there is an increased risk of aspiration (e.g., trauma, GI issues) but is not recommended for cardiac arrest patients.
  • Preoxygenation, muscle relaxants, and the high-volume low-pressure cuff are important components of RSI.
